description: Find large files (>500MB) in home directory
example: This command will list all files larger than 500MB in your home directory, showing their sizes in human-readable format
notes: Use with caution in production environments.

description: Search for 'error' messages in system log
example: Use this command to quickly find system errors recorded in the syslog.
notes: Adjust log file path as needed.

description: Find a process by its name
example: This command will help you quickly identify a running process by its name.
notes: Replace [process_name] with the actual process name you are looking for.

description: List top 10 largest directories in current location.
example: Use to identify which folders consume the most disk space in the current directory
notes: Can be modified to use a specific path

description: Show disk space usage
example: Use this command to quickly view available disk space on your system.
notes: 'df' command is commonly used to report file system disk space usage.

description: Search command history
example: Helps find a previously entered command containing a specific word or phrase
notes: Replace [search_term] with the term you want to find in your history

description: Display system resource usage
example: Use this command to monitor real-time CPU, memory, and process usage.
notes: Press 'q' to exit

description: Set read/execute permissions for group/others, read/write/execute for user
example: Use to grant executable permissions to a script or folder.
notes: Replace [file_or_directory] with the target

description: Create a new directory
example: Use this command to make a new folder in the current directory.
notes: Replace [new_directory] with desired name.

description: Remove a directory recursively
example: Use with extreme caution, as this permanently removes directories and all content.
notes: Replace [directory]. Be very careful when using this command.

description: Copy a file
example: Copying a file to another location.
notes: Make sure you have permissions to access and modify the source and destination location

description: Rename or move a file or directory
example: Moves or renames a file in the file system.
notes: Can be used to move a file to a different directory or rename the file.

description: View the content of a file
example: Use to display the text within a file
notes: Replace [file] with the name of the file.

description: View a file, navigating through its content
example: Use for large files, allows page navigation instead of displaying the entire file at once.
notes: Press 'q' to exit

description: Display first 10 lines of a file
example: Use this command to quickly check the beginning of a file.
notes: Replace [file] with desired filename

description: Display last 10 lines of a file
example: Use this command to quickly check the end of a log file.
notes: Replace [file] with desired filename

description: Download a file from the web
example: Use this command to download a file from the specified URL.
notes: Replace [url] with the actual URL to download.

description: Download a file from the web using curl
example: Use this command to download a file from the specified URL and rename it.
notes: Replace [url] with the actual URL and [filename] with the desired name.

description: Test network connectivity to a host
example: Use to check network reachability of a server or website.
notes: Replace [host] with the actual hostname or IP address.

description: Connect to a remote server using SSH
example: Use to securely access a remote computer.
notes: Replace [user] with username and [host] with remote server address.

description: Securely copy files between remote server and local computer.
example: Use to transfer files to or from a remote server
notes: Replace the placeholders with the appropriate values.

description: Display network interface configuration
example: Use to view IP address, MAC address, and other network interface information
notes: Use 'ip addr' on some newer systems if 'ifconfig' doesn't exist

description: Display network connections, listening ports
example: Use to view which ports are open and listening for connections
notes: Provides details of active internet connections

description: Update package lists on Debian/Ubuntu systems
example: Use this command before installing new packages to ensure the package lists are up to date
notes: Requires sudo privileges.

description: Upgrade installed packages on Debian/Ubuntu systems
example: Use to update all installed software to their latest versions
notes: Requires sudo privileges and it should be performed with caution.

description: Install a package on Debian/Ubuntu systems
example: Use to install a specific software package.
notes: Replace [package_name] with the name of the package you want to install

description: Remove a package on Debian/Ubuntu systems
example: Use this command to uninstall a specific software package
notes: Replace [package_name] with the name of the package to be removed.

description: Update all installed packages on Red Hat systems
example: Use this command to update all installed software to their latest versions on RedHat systems
notes: Requires sudo privileges and should be used with caution

description: Install a new package on Red Hat systems
example: Use to install a new software package in a RedHat based system
notes: Replace [package_name] with the name of the package you want to install

description: Remove a package on Red Hat systems
example: Use to uninstall a software package in a RedHat based system
notes: Replace [package_name] with the name of the package to be removed.

description: Update Homebrew package list
example: Used to refresh your homebrew package listing
notes: Must have Homebrew installed

description: Upgrade outdated packages using Homebrew
example: Used to update your homebrew packages.
notes: Must have Homebrew installed

description: Install a new package with Homebrew
example: Use to install new software using the Homebrew package manager.
notes: Must have Homebrew installed. Replace [package_name]

description: Uninstall a package using Homebrew
example: Used to remove software using Homebrew.
notes: Must have Homebrew installed. Replace [package_name]

description: Clone a Git repository
example: Downloads a remote git repository to your local machine
notes: Replace [repository_url] with the actual URL.

description: Show status of changes in a Git repository
example: Displays modified, added and deleted files in the current repository.
notes: Must be in a git repository.

description: Add all changes in the current directory to the staging area.
example: Use this command to add all your modified files to the git staging area to later commit them.
notes: Must be in a git repository.

description: Commit staged changes with a message
example: Records the changes you've made to the repository along with a message.
notes: Replace [commit_message] with a brief description of your changes.

description: Upload local commits to remote repository
example: Use this command to publish all your changes to the remote repository
notes: Replace [branch_name] with the name of your branch.

description: Download changes from remote repository
example: Use this to update your local branch with the changes made remotely.
notes: Replace [branch_name] with the name of your branch.

description: List branches in the current git repo
example: Use this command to know which branches you have in the repo
notes: Must be inside a git repo

description: Switch to a different branch
example: Use this command to switch between branches
notes: Replace [branch_name] with the name of the branch you want to switch to.

description: Start a systemd service
example: Use this command to start a specific service.
notes: Requires sudo privileges. Replace [service_name]

description: Stop a systemd service
example: Use this command to stop a specific service.
notes: Requires sudo privileges. Replace [service_name]

description: Restart a systemd service
example: Use this command to restart a specific service.
notes: Requires sudo privileges. Replace [service_name]

description: Check the status of a systemd service
example: Use this command to see the status of a specific service.
notes: Requires sudo privileges. Replace [service_name]

description: Create a compressed tar archive
example: Use this command to compress a directory into a tar.gz archive.
notes: Replace [archive_name] and [directory_to_compress] with correct values

description: Extract files from a compressed tar archive
example: Use to extract files from a tar.gz archive.
notes: Replace [archive_name] with the correct name

description: Create a zip archive
example: Compresses multiple files into a single zip file.
notes: Replace [archive_name] and [files_to_zip] with correct values

description: Extract files from a zip archive
example: Use to extract a zip archive to the current location.
notes: Replace [archive_name] with the correct file name

description: Find empty directories in current location
example: Used to find and remove empty directories in the current path.
notes: Be careful when removing empty directories.
